Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Saw no sign s of instability while touring. Non planar fracture that was resting on 5cm layer of NSF.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit is adjacent to avalanche: crown

Pit_Observation.activities: We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Calm and clear conditions, wind buff forming in some areas, but intermixed with areas of unconsolidated surface conditions. Overall the snow overlaying the existing rain crust (above facets) was cohesive and fairly dense. Boot penetration to calf. ECTP17 failed at the rain crust.

1 finger hardness layers near 75 cm are the weak layers that formed just before new years. They are not a concern in this pit. I could not get them to break, even when prying the column with my shovel. These layers last caused avalanches in this area on Jan 4th. Total snowfall since New Years has contained over 8 inches of water.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit is adjacent to avalanche: crown
Pit_Observation.pitNotes:
The day after the incident we experienced large collapses on an adjacent ridge. We did not approach the crown on this day.
This profile was completed a week after the incident. From the surface to 86 cm is new and wind-blown snow since the avalanche occurred. The profile was done in the center-right portion of the crown. The average crown depths near this section of the crown were ~55 cm. Stability test scores on this day were ECTX (x2) and PST 30 and 33/100 end @ 22 cm.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit is adjacent to avalanche: other
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: This profile was taken about 100 feet north of the flank of fatal avalanche. We did not do a crown profile because there was too much hangfire. The weak layer was a layer of very light snow that faceted slightly between Christmas and New Years. Ten days ago and 5 miles south, we consistently got ECTP5 to ECTP15 on this layer. In the same area 5 days ago we got inconsistent ECT results, the ones that were ECTP had scores in the low 20s. In this pit the ECTN fractured across half the column. 50 feet north in another pit, this layer would not break at all in an ECT. There has been very little to no avalanche activity or other obvious signs of instability on this layer.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Hazy thin cloud cover had moved in within the last hour.

Pit dug above the top of 3. Steep temperature gradient has promoted faceting in the majority of the snowpack. This area received minimal snow transport, and what was left will likely facet out in the near future. Tests revealed low propagation propensity due to the weak overlying slab, however the possibility for propagation is still there. How will a large load on this rotten snowpack affect the stability of these lower elevation areas?

With Ryan Mathis - Telluride Ski Patrol Structure is deteriorating. Large temperature gradient near the ground is driving faceted crystal and depth hoar growth. Currently stable but if these conditions persist, the next big load greater than 1.5-2 inches SWE in a short duration may tip the scales toward a deep slab cycle.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Pit dug by Cam Johnson and Blase Reardon MUCH deeper snowpack than expected at low elevations. ECT failed on graupel and decomposing fragmented particles just below the most recent crust.
In the scree field but away from where people travel downhill to preserve pit integrity

Dug on a 15m roll beneath treed bench in a sparsely treed Meadow. Between rider's L most Apostles
Easy Shovel Tilt Tests produced failure in PPsd FCsf layer @214cm (down 20cm). Several (5) D0.5 avalanches Sr15m were triggered on steeper lee features around 40deg from benign terrain. Reports of these were reported on radioby XCan group in adjacent terrain ECTX @ 95cm (down 140cm) Propagated with significant post test effort DTT 12,13 SC @ 25cm (down 210cm)
Low angle terrain. Sparse trees. Area potentially exposed to sun effect from previous high pressure system. New loading. Ski tracks near by. Looking for basal facets

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area; Pit is representative of backcountry; Recent activity on different slopes
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Type: Test Site: TL, sparsely treed, open to sky, base of talus slope Observers: LW, BE Stability Tests: ECTN and CTM RP at storm interfaces dn 20-80cm
Entire snowpack is deteriorating. Large temperature gradient exists driving faceted crystal growth both mid pack and at the ground. Weakest snow is at 80cm above a 1 finger hard layer at 60-20 cm.
Uncompacted - might be a shallow spot

Pit_Observation.activities: Recent activity on similar slopes; Instability rapidly rising
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: We aborted our ascent due to increasing temps, solar effect and evidence of SS D2 on similar slopes. Too much overhead to safely continue. We dug a pit to gather data in a safe but similar aspect. Open slope near Ski Lake. Dirt ground.
botten av sten och mossa, läsida.

Mjög hvasst og mikill skafrenningur. Snjóþekjan er mjög misdreifð og situr í lægðum. Það voru víða snjóblolta rúllingar í um 100 til 200 m hæð. Góð bynding við eldri snjó. Stöðuleiki við eldri snjó getur verið minni ofar þar sem eldri snjór er kaldari.
Gunners right side of Graveline Gulch start zone
Poor structure, but not reactive in tests. Layer of greatest concern is midpack (below crust at 37 cm).

Junky snowpack with numerous crusts and associated faceted layers. Overall structure poor but lacking any cohesive slab so no real energy or relevant test results. I'd anticipate new storm snow instabilities or wind slabs to easily step down or at least gouge into some of these MF/FC layers as they run.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area; We skied slope

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Soft, junky snowpack. Tests revealed progressive compression and broken results on several of the Fc/Cr combos but lacking a real slab or any bridging strength in the crusts potential for future persistent slab problems looks minimal.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Norðan við gryfjuna hafði fallið snjófló sem er ca 250-300m br, brotstál sjáanlegt ca 10cm undan kjettabelti í Íllviðrishnjúk siðri. Þetta svæði er í skjóli fyrir vestan og suð-vestan-átt.
Ironton parking lot. No Ski pen observed.

Pit_Observation.activities: Recent activity on different slopes; We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: HMH Recon 1-10-2020. Pit dug in usual spot 100' Below Ridge, 200' South of LZ. Pit was dug 600' Uphill from SS-AB-R2D2.5-I from 2# Airblast. Failed initially within storm layer then stepped down to sun crust @ 80cm. No Cracking, No Collapsing, No Whoomphing. On the next run we experienced slopewide collapse (No failure) on opposite aspect of same peak on Squirt Glades, that had previously cycled in December. 23# Shot was placed aerially on slope that morning with no results. HS was 135 with 1M New on 35CM FC/DH/MF. Pit Results were ECTP14 @ 35CM.
